value: When we start working with our ancestry, some questions come to our mind: - Who are my ancestors? How can I make my family's tree? Which person is my oldest ancestor known? Which software should I use to work? Are blogs talking about family history correct? On this page, we bring answers to these questions to help you find your ancestors.

The first suggested step is to talk about the family with the oldest relatives, because these people probably live together with ancestors present in other generations. During this talk, ask them for some documents from them and other ancestors. Enjoy the moment and ask them to talk about some family's history, but it is a good approach to confirm each history you heard, to be sure they were real.

After getting documentation with near ancestors, the next step is to get documents with governmental organizations or companies responsible to archive them. In the past, we did not have the same documents we have nowadays, we should prepare ourselves for issues, that are not barriers, but they are opportunities to learn. In the Brazil, I followed the next steps to find my ancestors:

  • Request birth certificate, marriage certificate and certificate of death of each one of your ancestors and, when necessary, of their brothers and sisters.
  • Look for available documents in museums.
  • Look for papers in newspapers (Memória, Biblioteca Nacional) during person's lifetime.
  • If your country did not have separation between State and Church, you will need to research in religious documents. Look for churches where your ancestor lived and when you cannot find anything, look for documents inside the monastery or diocese. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has some old religious documents inside their Family Search project.
  • When we start researching around the 17th and 16th centuries, we have inventories and testaments available in São Paulo, we also have local old documentation (Volume I e Volume II). It is also available in documents from São Paulo Town Hall.
  • Scientific publications like Instituto Histórico Geográfico de São Paulo magazine, the magazine of Instituto Histórico e Geográfico do Espírito Santo, Revista Genea, and also ASBRAP magazines are good references, but they are not the final word about an ancestor, because scientific papers can be reviewed with new data like it happened in ASBRAP magazine: In magazine 6th edition, Marta Amato published new data about Francisca de Macedo updating previous understanding published in magazine 4th edition for Cid Guimarães. The site projeto compartilhar is not a scientific magazine, but the authors made genealogical trees using primary sources, so we also assume the site as a reference.
  • When we talk about genealogical works, we have books made after deep research published for Nuno Borrego, Manuel Abranches de Soveral, we also have works made for Christian Settipani, José Mattoso e José Augusto de Sottomayor-Pizarro. I do not have doubts that there are more publications from other researchers, but I am only citing the authors that I studied deeply, and I am sure that their publications follow the scientific method.
  • When we reach the Middle Ages, it is necessary to research inside Indexes and after this, the Chancelaria Régia, to find possible ancestors. Another source of information present in 'Torre do Tombo' are the Inquirições Gerais and documents that were in control of churches like Cabido da Sé de Coimbra, and also inquisition documents like Lisboa Inquisition.
  • To return even more in our history, it will be necessary to study chronicles that talk about the history of a specific region.

Genealogy is a science, so a research must be aligned to the scientific method that has as basis: the reproducibility of a proposal and a clear rejection propose, in other words, when an information is reported about a person, the same information can be confirmed or rejected for another researcher, because it is aligned with primary sources.

There are different software and sites to help users to make their genealogical tree, but tools that I have tested do not check information added, so our suggestion is to use them with caution and always have your family's tree locally, mainly when you are using collaborative sites.

About the blogs, it is necessary to have the same attention we have with books and paper. Sometimes blogs' authors moved by passion select the wrong roads to reach a goal, instead of showing what documents are really talking about their families. This is a complex scenario, so it is suggested to the reader to take a look at blogs of other scientists and collaborators, and take a look at their sources, to understand how people are making their research:

  • Site about (Leme's family).
